identified-content.object.title: CHRONICLE (TIMES COLUMN)

block.p: Taking the chair held by the late Barbara W. Tuchman, ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE has been elected to the 50-member American Academy of Arts and Letters. Members are chosen for special distinction from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, the parent organization. The honor is among the most important in the arts in the United States.

Mrs. Huxtable, 69 years old, was the architecture critic for The New York Times from 1963 to 1982 and was on the paper's editorial board from 1973 to 1982. Previously, she had worked as assistant curator of architecture at the Museum of Modern Art.
In 1970, she won the first Pulitzer Prize for criticism and in 1981 she received a MacArthur Foundation Fellowship. She was elected to the institute in 1977.
